positive.review:
I don't believe I can put into words how much I love this game. It got added to my Steam family library months and months ago and I played it immediately because it just looked cool, I ended up purchasing it for myself just to support the devs because, my god. Before the recent major updates that has given me more content to work on, I'd literally play through the entire game over and over again.

First, the actual gameplay is spectacular. It's just fun, satisfying, hands-down the best cleaning simulator I've played. The before/after of the scenes is pretty remarkable, and everything can be done relatively quickly. A lot of neat mechanics, like detergents, breaking glass/other objects, evidence collection that reveals the story of the scene, UV lights, parkour is even a thing?

The music of this game is fantastic as well. Another mechanic is collecting music tapes/disks which you can then play from your tablet while you clean from then on out. Each of the songs is a genuine song published somewhere IRL--I'm not exactly certain how they were chosen/if the more recent songs were made for a collab/exactly how all that happened, exactly, but the music and sound is well-thought-out.

And then the story. The story is fully cohesive, it's not just random levels to choose from. You play as a janitor named Kovalsky (cleaning crime scenes to cover for murder as opposed to cleaning places post-investigation), and I'm not going to get into it too much for the sake of spoilers, but the guy has a valid reason for what he does and it's easy enough to simultaneously sympathize with him and understand that, y'know, covering up murders is ethically screwed up. Kovalsky's character is sort of a joy to play as, actively commenting on the scene that you're cleaning or the evidence you find. He's sarcastic and sardonic, you can tell he kinda hates what he has to do and covers it with humor. Each of the maps is super varied, and there's a lot of story behind what happened, why the people involved are dead, either tying into the overarching storyline or a separate, fully cohesive story branch. This could easily be a novel, which is saying a LOT for a game that's primarily just the satisfaction of mopping up blood, and why my praises are so high. Some things in this game are absolutely heart-wrenching, do be warned.

Nightmare Mode is a newer addition that basically doubled the content. Every chapter being completely reworked and ANOTHER storyline embedded into an already fantastic story. Also some fairly severe horror elements, but very few jumpscares. More like it makes you FEEL like you're going to get jumpscared. It ALSO introduces a music disk system that's an extension of the music tape system I mentioned before. A whole lot of fun.

And then the updates. The devs are actively working SO hard on this game. I played and then bought this game around a year ago when it was nothing but one chapter flat-out, and since then, we've gotten Nightmare Mode, two new Community levels, True Cleaner mode on all levels, and a collection of different skins for most of the main items you use for cleaning. I do believe Chapter 2 is on the way as well. In other words, it's well worth the money spent, in my opinion.

Also, most importantly, you can pet the damn dog and get an achievement for doing it enough times. 10/10 game just for that.
Recommending this game 100%. The combination of cleaning and terror of the story, and experience is indescribable. Absolute cinema.

I understand it saves a lot on time for the voices and images, but now that the game has over a million sales, the least they could do was hire some actual voice actors, you know?

Anyways- The above is still true! A fun game that has definitely made me laugh while scrubbing away stains.

[h1] Let me tell you, I did *not* expect to absolutely LOVE this game so much! [/h1]

The devs should also be commended because they're the shining example of how things should be done - they added whole game's worth of content in FREE updates (nightmare mode for EVERY level and later on "communiti patch" with two new levels).

One of the best cleaning-duty games I've played! 

The physics aren't as annoying as some others (VCD, I mean you) and hold up the entire game. 

Levels are diverse and engaging, offering plenty of nooks, crannies and secrets. There's reason to play each elvel 3 times; a nightmare mode that transforms the levels in a nightmarish version of the original, which I found entertaining! The True Cleaner mode is basically a hard mode of the original where you can't use every upgrade and can't use your cleaner-sense to see if you missed spots. Both extra modes unlock skins, some of which are really nicely done (laser cleaner and black hole for example).

There's an overarching storyline which is well done and adds to the experience. Skill tree to increase effectiveness of your tools and unlock new (better) ones as well.

All in all quite a good game. About 40 hours to to all regular levels and nightmare ones (and find all secrets). It'll add another 10-15 (20?) hours to do all maps in True Cleaner as well for the last skins I miss.

I downloaded Crime Scene Cleaner thinking it‚Äôd be a cute little cleanup game. Nope. I‚Äôm in here scrubbing walls like I‚Äôm paying off a felony I didn‚Äôt commit. I‚Äôve never had a mop judge me so hard. Every time I miss a spot, it‚Äôs like the game whispers, ‚ÄúSo‚Ä¶ you just don‚Äôt care about your life, huh?‚Äù

The blood smears slide around like they‚Äôre late for work, the evidence hides better than my ex when rent was due, and I‚Äôm out here picking up limbs like it‚Äôs just another Tuesday.

But the worst part? It‚Äôs actually so satisfying. I clean one room and suddenly I‚Äôm thinking, ‚ÄúMaybe I am a responsible adult.‚Äù (Narrator: they were not.)

If you like chaos, cleaning, and pretending you‚Äôre the world‚Äôs chillest crime janitor, this is your game.
10/10 would bleach things I don‚Äôt understand again.

The perfect game to compliment a podcast or audiobook while still being VERY enjoyable without one. 

I originally wanted this game to serve as my time-killer. I needed a game for times that I didn't feel like committing to any particular game (we all know the feeling), and I ended up actually WANTING an excuse to play this game. 
 
Cleaning is satisfying, and its the only time you will ever see a room littered with trash and think... [i]Hell yes.[/i] After 100%ing this game, I can say I was only ever overwhelmed twice‚Äîboth in the same level. The museum... Both times I played this level, on normal and on nightmare, I got off before finishing. Unlock the cleaner sense ability that lets you see missing furniture so you don't lose your mind. 

You will develop your own routine to cleaning, and it is incredibly satisfying to get into that cleaning flow-state. You will fly through levels throwing furniture into adjacent rooms, smashing boxes, throwing bodies down stairs/ledges, and mopping up comical amounts of blood in super quick times. Every level you complete you get a sizeable amount of skill points if you had put in the time to perfect and search everything. Each upgrade feels meaningful and powerful.

The Nightmare mode shakes things up and gives you basically entirely new levels for you to put your fully upgraded Kowalski to work. Nightmare mode adds double the blood, trash, and bodies, and even gives you puzzles to solve, all whilst being fun and spooky. This mode offers a very satisfying endgame, and you unlock really cool skins for your tools for each nightmare level you beat. 

The game also does not overstay its welcome. I would love more levels, but I feel like it is the perfect length. 
Buy the game.

As a big fan of Viscera Cleanup Detail, I often found it was hard to scratch the same itch with any other cleaning game.

However, Crime Scene Cleaner was a pleasant surprise that help to scratch that same itch. It approaches the grimy, messy cleanup job in a more casual way. Cleanup is broken down into larger tasks rather than tedious small fixes like in games like Viscera Cleanup Detail. This isn't a bad thing by any means, as it allows for a more chill and relaxed experience. The ambience and the entertaining story make for a really high-quality, easygoing time just cleaning up your average crime scene.

The game provides a small skill tree for each of your cleaning aspects, which will ultimately be maxed out as you continue to play the game. There's fun secrets and collectibles to find for the "explorers" as well.

As if the base game wasn't fun enough, the devs have continued to add more things to clean and do. As of this review, they have added Nightmare versions of the base maps of the game, and have even added a brand new community-made map into the game.

These Nightmare maps are not just a reskin of the base maps, they are re-envisioned and re-adjusted with new things to do, clean, and experience.

Crime Scene Cleaner is a casual and well-polished game in the "cleaning" side of gaming. It's hard NOT to recommend this game in it's current state. It's well worth the price, but also goes on sale a fair amount of the time. 

Highly recommend!

PS at no point in this game are you under threat, and I have only been jump-scared twice... the band stage and mannequins.

Please keep supporting this game devs, and we will keep playing!

In my opinion, Crime Scene Cleaner was *already* the best entry in the surprisingly small "cleaning simulator" genre - and that was *before* I came back this year to discover Nightmare mode, essentially an entire additional game with an astounding amount of passion put into it.

In terms of the basic game, not only does this scratch the aesthetically pleasing itch that all cleaning games do, but it has a considerable surface area of cleaning options - I find myself trying to be more effective in my cleaning in interesting ways.  Some subtle gameplay to keep you engaged, but never enough to take away from the simple joy of cleaning a messy area.

The plot, while simple, is such an excellent addition.  Some very fun narratives to follow, both within each level and across the overall game, and really great voice acting.  Great hidden references and funny moments, but also some disarmingly poignant experiences as well.

Easy recommend.

I picked up this game on a whim during the Halloween sale. It sounded like something that was in my wheelhouse, and I saw reviews commenting that it was similar to Viscera Cleanup Detail, but with voice acting and a bit more of a continuous story.

I ended up being very disappointed with my purchase, and I wish I'd delved a little deeper before getting stuck in.

While the core gameplay loop is just about what it says on the tin, I found a lot of the "Bells and Whistles" that sold me on the game were lacking and downright off-putting. 

I noticed that there were quite a few instances of awkward phrasing or inflection from the voice acting, especially from the main character. After hearing a bit of it, a friend asked if it was AI; I researched into that after they asked, and found that there is a voice actor listed, and the devs have apparently commented on this question before, saying that the voices are not AI-generated. Still, I wonder if they used generative AI to tweak some phrasings or generate further lines from the original voice actor. Either way, though, I found the voice acting to be a real disappointment. 

I also found the story itself to be disjointed and not especially well knit together. It felt like a lot of hints would get sprinkled in to connect a through-thread, but then abandoned, or else not quite bridged.

For example, [spoiler] I thought that the game was trying to lay bread crumbs for Big Jim being overly paranoid, and have some sort of payoff for that as the jobs continued, as it became more clear through context clues that he had killed people that weren't out to get him at all. But instead, the payoff was that someone had been out to get him in one of the levels? And there also wasn't really a satisfying resolution to all of that. There didn't even super feel like a payoff for the main character getting the money he needed, it just sort of...ended. [/spoiler]

And to be clear, I would have been perfectly happy to play a lot of disconnected episodes of this type of game; idle, perfectionist cleaning of different locations is an idle sort of game for me, akin to Powerwash Simulator or the aforementioned Viscera Cleanup Detail. However, having a connected story through the levels was a feature that was supposed to set the game apart, and it instead felt like a poorly constructed facade over the bones of the game.

It was a lot of these touches that just made me not vibe with the game. In addition, I found out after trying to research about the possibility of the voices being AI that there was some discussion among other players that many of the paintings, photos, and other assets used in the game may have been AI-generated, which distressed me greatly. I've taken great pains to stay away from any games that use generative AI content, and Steam has been pretty good about this, as I understood that any games are required to contain a disclaimer about their use, and this game had no such disclaimer. 

I couldn't find any statement from the devs regarding the use of generative AI one way or the other, but if I'd known that there was wide speculation I probably wouldn't have purchased the game unless I got a definitive answer.

Even if there weren't generative AI used, though, I honestly thought there were a lot of disappointing things about this game, and I wish I'd spent the time checking out some other games instead.

BE WARNED, FOR THOSE WITH INTEL GRAPHICS OR INTEGRATED GRAPHICS CARDS, THIS GAME WILL NOT WORK FOR YOU. 

I would really love to see why this game is so hyped up, but unfortunately it appears that integrated graphics are not supported. The game crashes if you attempt to play almost instantly, and it remains unplayable. I have never seen a game that fails to support Intel graphics that is so popular. And the fact that it isn't shown or warned anywhere but the little tiny requirements section under all the other information makes it hard to find out why the game didn't work in the first place. If the game becomes playable for users with these hardware limitations I will happily update my review but until then, I cannot reccomend this game for anyone with Intel graphics or integrated graphics cards.

The first few stages are fun, and it is very satisfying to clean up blood and bodies and put furniture back in place. I enjoyed the small stories you explore at each scene, especially the possessed roomba doing a satanic ritual. Top notch entertainment there. 

But everything else is pretty bad. Some of the cleaning tools are buggy, especially in Nightmare mode, and the writing clearly isn't proofread, containing lots of nice immersion-breaking dialectical inconsistencies. 

The main plotline goes literally nowhere - the guy is working for a mob boss to save his daughter and the mob boss becomes increasingly suspicious of people closer to him, calling hits on them and saying that cleaner man is the only one he can trust... foreshadowing, right? Nah. The intrigue is for nothing. I won't say what happens at the end, but imagine the most boring way this story could resolve, and it's that.

The voice acting is really... weird? It's bad in a very strange way. The accents are all over the place and some of the words are garbled in ways I've never heard. I'm almost tempted to say the voices are AI, but I have no proof of that. Considering the AI used in some of the prop art though, I wouldn't be surprised, and that makes me sad.

Overall, save your money for a different game that does the same premise better.

Cons: AI slop artworks everywhere. Soured my impression on the game significantly. there is AI generated images used for paintings, pictures and posters and it is undisclosed on the store page. honestly, i'm really baffled as to why stock images weren't used; none of the images needed to be custom.
i get that this is the world we live in now but i try to stay as far from generative AI as i can. i decided to just give this game a chance even after i noticed the assets but i continued to feel guilty (especially in an art gallery level which felt particularly ironic) and after finishing the game and digesting my experience i can say i do regret compromising on my morals.
i also have a personal method for gauging how "worth it" a game purchase is, that being: if i enjoyed one hour for every dollar spent then it was worth it. while i recognize i could get more time out of this game (if i wanted to) since there is more content like different modes, i dont think it meets my requirements for a good purchase- morals aside.
anyway, ignoring my issues with the AI assets and looking at just the game in a vacuum it is indeed good or at least above average (i think my favorite thing was just the water effect when you mop the floor, it's very satisfying). but honestly, just play powerwash sim or viscera cleanup.
